author: Sarah Carty
title: Parents of Caleb Schwab killed on water slide speak out Yahoo7 Be - Yahoo7
text:
Share Parents of Caleb Schwab killed on water slide speak out Yahoo7 Be - Yahoo7 
The parents of a 10-year-old boy who was killed on a water slide have revealed their heartache over the tragedy. Close Parents of boy killed on waterslide speak for the first time UP NEXT VIDEO Parents of boy killed on waterslide speak for the first time. Source: Good Morning America Parents of boy killed on waterslide speak for the first time 
Caleb Schwab died last August when he was thrown from the world’s tallest water slide, called Verrückt, at Schlitterbahn waterpark in Kansas City. 
Scott and Michelle Schwab took their four boys to the park for a family fun day but tragically only three of their precious sons came back. Caleb Schwab died when he was thrown from the Verrückt water slide in Kansas City. Photo: AAP 
As soon as the family got to the park, two of their sons, 10-year-old Caleb and 12-year-old Nathan rushed for the Verrückt water slide, which translates to ‘insane’ in German. 
The slide is known as the tallest of its kind in the world, measuring 168-foot tall and before the boys went on it, their father told them to stick together. 
"Before they took off I said, 'Brother's stick together', 'I know Dad'. I said, 'Look at me, brother's stick together',” Scott told ABC News . 
Nathan waited for his brother at the end of the slide but within moments his parents heard his screams. 
"He was screaming, 'He flew from Verrückt, he flew from Verrückt'," Michelle said. WATCH: @ABC News Exclusive: Parents speak out about water park tragedy; 10-year-old killed on world's tallest water slide. pic.twitter.com/M460GdMW6S — Good Morning America (@GMA) February 13, 2017 
One witness, who spoke to ABC News said it appeared that Caleb had been decapitated on the slide and tried to keep his parents from seeing his body. 
"There was a gentlemen who wouldn’t allow me to come close enough to see what was going on," Michelle told Good Morning America. 
"He just kept saying, 'No trust me, you don’t want to go any further'." 
Scott said he just kept asking if his son was dead before a witness confirmed the devastating news. 
Scott and Michelle have settled with the park for an undisclosed sum. 
They claim the biggest thing they miss most about their son is giving him a hug and a kiss every morning.
